children.text: By Right of Birth (1921) and Trooper of Troop K (1916) Introductory Essay
The surviving footage of
By Right of Birth

(1921) is among the earliest extant productions by an African American company. It was the fifth—and last—release from the Lincoln Motion Picture Company, a pioneering “race film” studio that served Black and mixedrace audiences in the 1910s and early 1920s. Founded in 1916, Lincoln not only galvanized the race film industry with its five features; it also built a national distribution network and helped launch the career of Oscar Micheaux.
Because several reels and intertitles are missing,
By Right of Birth

can be challenging to follow. This AVAnnotate project guides viewers through the surviving narrative while providing background on the cast, production, historical context, and the film’s circulation.
By Right of Birth
centers on the story of Juanita, a young woman of Black and Muscogee descent whose claim to an oil-rich allotment attracts scheming speculators.
It is impossible to determine certain definitive aspects of
By Right of Birth
and its script. Multiple undated versions of the script and scenario (the story upon which the script is based) survive in the Lincoln archives. Moreover, audiences viewed different versions of
By Right of Birth

. Scenes were cut on the road to satisfy local censors or to replace damaged reels. Rather than presuming a single authoritative version, this summary and larger AVAnnotate project embraces the film’s fluid, adaptive nature and draws chiefly on documents in the George P. Johnson Collection and reviews in the Black press.

children.text: Summary of
By Right of Birth
The film opens with a wagon plunging off a cliff. Soon afterward, California rancher
Frank Cooper

comes upon the wreck and finds a crying infant on the riverbank. The father has died; the mother is nowhere to be found. The only clue to the child’s identity is a Bible noting her date of birth. Assuming the lightskinned baby is Native or Mexican, Cooper adopts her and names her
Juanita.
(Some archival notes describe Cooper as “supposedly of Indian ancestry,” while others present him as white, underscoring the film’s flexible treatment of race.)
Juanita matures into a popular college student in Southern California. Frank adores her, but his wife,
Geraldine Cooper
—a bridge-obsessed social climber mired in debt—shows little affection. During a horseback ride, Juanita is thrown from her horse and rescued by
Philip
, a charismatic Black track star and law student. Mutual attraction sparks, yet both suppress it because the era’s racial strictures forbid interracial romance.
Desperate for money, Mrs. Cooper allies with
Manuel Romero
, a crooked Mexican American attorney and oil speculator. Romero has learned of an unclaimed Muscogee Freedmen allotment that sits on oil-rich land and hires bumbling detective
Pinky Webb
to locate the heir. As he investigates, Mrs. Cooper begins to suspect that Juanita herself may be the missing allottee—and therefore of Black descent.

children.caption: One of the many versions of the By Right of Birth scenario found in George P. Johnson's collection at UCLA.

children.text: Juanita overhears Mrs. Cooper voicing these suspicions to Frank. Believing she no longer belongs in her adoptive household, she leaves, breaking her father’s heart. Confiding in Philip, she finds solace at a girls’ home run by the kindly
Mother Agnes.

Romero confirms Juanita’s identity, falsely claims the land is worthless, and has her sign it away for $1,000. When Philip tries to intervene, Romero orders Webb to hold the couple at gunpoint. Juanita and Philip outwit the detective, escape, and pursue the speculator in a frantic car chase; Romero is killed when he is flung from his vehicle before he can file the deed.

Back at Mother Agnes’s home, Juanita unpacks the Bible found with her as an infant. Mother Agnes recognizes it instantly—it was hers—revealing that she is Juanita’s long-lost mother. The film ends happily with an announcement of Juanita and Philip’s engagement.
Historical Context

Indian Territory at the turn of the twentieth century was undergoing tremendous change. Earlier in the nineteenth century, treaties with the United States government—along with the Indian Removal Act of 1830—had led to the forced removal of dozens of Native Nations to lands west of the Mississippi River. During the Trail of Tears, Cherokee, Muscogee (Creek), Seminole, Chickasaw, and Choctaw Nations—often referred to in that period as the Five “Civilized” Tribes—were compelled to migrate to Indian Territory, bringing with them enslaved Black people who later became known as “Indian Freedmen.” Many Freedmen married or had children with citizens of the Five Tribes. The post–Civil War treaties of 1866 extended a measure of tribal citizenship to the formerly enslaved people of these Nations.

With the 1898 Curtis Act, tribal governments were dismantled and communally held lands were divided into individual allotments. Indian Freedmen typically received smaller tracts of land and lower annuity payments than citizens listed as “by blood.” The Muscogee (Creek) Nation, however, allotted Muscogee Freedmen the same 160-acre parcels as its “by blood” citizens.

To determine who was eligible to receive allotments and annuities, the US Government had the Dawes Commission compile a list of citizens of the Five Tribes. This was known as the Dawes Rolls. The Dawes Commission created separate lists for those it determined “Indians by blood” and “Freedmen” members of each nation. In doing so, the process intensified pre-existing racial divisions and produced new ones by classifying citizens of the Five Tribes into categories rooted in U.S. racial logic rather than Indigenous notions of kinship. Many Black Native people, regardless of deep community ties, were placed on the Freedmen roll. Their allotments became prime targets for speculators who used forged deeds, guardianships, and courtroom maneuvers to pry mineral rights away for pennies on the dollar. After statehood, when Indian Territory became what is now known as Oklahoma, US American segregation practices and laws fixed those racial categories into everyday life, dictating where people could live, attend school, ride streetcars, or marry. Many Black Natives left the state, some of whom settled in places such as California, along with the thousands of African Americans from the south, who moved north and west during the Great Migration.

children.caption: A two-page advertisement for the premiere of By Right of Birth at the Trinity Auditorium, 1921. From the George P. Johnson collection at UCLA.

children.text: By Right of Birth

(1921) is set against the backdrop of these historical changes. With Oklahoma’s transition into statehood, it has traded the more fluid boundaries of Indian Territory for a rigid Jim Crow order that governs nearly every encounter across Black, Native, and white people. The film’s villain, attorney Manuel Romero, scours the Dawes rolls for a “missing Creek Freedman” whose oil-rich allotment he hopes to acquire for a mere $1,000. His scheme dramatizes the intersection of race, property, and fraud which divested thousands of Native Americans—including those with Black ancestry—of their land. Romero’s desperate dash to file paperwork before the courthouse closes echoes the cut-throat race for deeds and leases that decided fortunes in early twentieth century Oklahoma. While many depictions of these events frame them solely through the lens of White/Native relations, the film offers a rare contemporary Black perspective on how allotment policy, legal bureaucracy, and settler colonialism combined to dispossess both Native and Black citizens.

Juanita’s ambiguous identity dramatizes the era’s obsession with racial categorization. She grows up in a world where the Dawes Commission and Jim Crow segregation have fixed people into legal boxes. The mere suspicion that she might be “Colored” (Black) is enough to compel her to depart from her adoptive household. Meanwhile, the intersection of her racial status and political status as a Muscogee Freedmen makes her a target of a scheme to steal her land. The film’s characters—Black hero, Mexican American villain, white (possibly Native) guardian, and Native/Black heir—thus map onto a landscape where segregation hardened, blood quantum came to reshape definitions of tribal citizenship, and economic opportunity flowed toward those who manipulated the new racial bureaucracy that arrived with the Curtis Act and statehood.
Finally, a close look at the surviving fragment of
By Right of Birth

(1921) reveals a hidden easter egg: a short clip from another film produced in 1916 that mysteriously ended up spliced into the footage. In 2022, film historian Cara Caddoo compared stills, production records, and actor credits and showed that this stray footage is actually from Lincoln Motion Picture Company’s earlier drama
The Trooper of Troop K
(1916/17), long presumed lost. The footage from
The Trooper of Troop K
begins just around the 1:40 second mark of
By Right of Birth

. Two actors--Jimmie Smith and Beulah Hall--lounge on a front stoop. Inside an “iris” matte in the upper corner, a uniformed cavalryman tenderly gazes up at a woman with a flower in her hair.  The clothing, cactus‑studded backdrop of the remaining intertitle, and above all the unmistakable face of Noble Johnson signal that this bit of film is part of
The Trooper of Troop K
(1916). As such, those eight seconds constitute the earliest known surviving fragment of a film produced by a Black American company.

Both the
Trooper of Troop K
and
By Right of Birth

were distributed through a network of film exchanges established by the Lincoln Motion Picture Company in cities such as Chicago, New Orleans, New York City, Philadelphia, Atlanta George, and St. Louis, Missouri. George P. Johnson operated the booking office in Omaha, Nebraska, before relocating to Los Angeles for the production of
By Right of Birth
. Additionally, traveling representatives of the company took the films on the road, booking exhibitions in smaller and harder to reach locations.
